addressleaf.section:
Copie of my l
re
to my L. T
re
r 30 J
a
95

page.lettertext:
fol.40r
May it please yo
r
good L. Since I made my last dispatche,
the 15 of this moneth, I have prevailed so farre,
by some privat endevo
rs
, w
t
certaine of
e
States,
as by meanes of their persuasion,
e rest of their Col-
legues of
e general States, deputed
M
r
Barne-
velt,
and M
r
Brinnen, to repaire unto me ye-
sterday, to knowe
e meaning of those speeches,
at I uttered unto them, at my last proposition,
by way of advise, as I advertised yo
r
L. the 4 of
this p
nt
. They beganne w
t
thankes from
e States and other complements of Wordes, for
e
special care
at I had taken, to devise some ready
meanes, to compose
e present difference between
her
Ma
tie
and them, and to project in their be-
half suche a course of proceeding, as would
give her cause to thinke better of their affections
unto her. What might followe suche a preface,
yo
r
L. will conceave, together w
t
at answear,
w
ch
I might make unto it. Wherein when I came
to
e pointes of
e Ouverture, I founde it very re-
quisit, w
t
preadvise of M
r
Barnevelt, to make
a change in some sort, of the forme of my proposal,
and
e number of
e articles, and of
e annual
su
m
es of paiment, w
t
some other alterations, to
dasell them a litle: but alwayes so as it might
serve, for a very litle inducement, to drawe them
to doe
at, which
e project did intend, and
M
r
Barnevelt would prosecute. For if I had
concurred w
t
e very same plotte,
at he had formerly
proposed, at his being in
Zyricksea,
because it
might have happened
at some heere of
e States,
had bin secretly told it, by some frind of that
conference, it would have wrought a great
suspition of intelligence between us, and thereby
fol.40v
bredde some other jalousies, then were to be neglected
In w
ch
respect I thought it meete, to varie somew
at
from him, and because it was but done, to serve
e
present turne, I hold it as impertinment, to be rela-
ted to yo
r
L. But of
e progresse, and
e substance,
of that w
ch
I negotiat, I will not comitte, any ne-
cessarie circumstance: having brought it already
to a very good passe, in that the assembly of
e
States is seased of
e mater, at their owne requi-
sition. For hardly would yo
r
L. beleeve of their
humo
rs
,
at they should be so nice and delicat to
deale w
t
: in so muche as if at first I had poured
out at once, all
e pointes of my Ouverture, however
I had qualified my speeches unto them, w
t
appa-
rances of profit to
e State of their Contrey, it would
undoubtedly have astonied and not persuaded
them
all
a whitte
: so as I doubt the very motion would
have dashed it self, at
e very first [occurrence],
and there afer, their good liking, to listen unto it,
would have growen irrecouverable. For every nou-
veltie unto them, where
e mater is of weight, is
greatly suspected: and I doe plainely perceave it,
at they have ever some distrust of
e English pro-
eedinges, howe cleerely soever we may deale in
our causes, w
ch
puttes me often to my shiftes, howe
to speake or to treat w
t
any one of them all.
But yet in this negotiation I have spedde beyond
my hope, of a favorable issue, for as farre as I have
brought it, and for so short a poursuite. I may
imagine very safely upon this their deputation, and
by divers tokens otherwise,
at it is not yet surmised
that there passeth in secret any special correspon-
dence between me and M
r
Barnevelt. W
ch
is a very
great helpe, both to him and to me, for
e maneging
of our businesse, w
t
more securitie in many thinges
fol.41r
and most of all in this,
at he was thus appointed,
to come and conferre, and after to report my spee-
ches to
e States: w
ch
he may doe to my advantage,
and for the furtherance of
e Project, in the ma-
ner of his deliverie: Wherein I am assured, he
wilbe diligent, and carefull. Howe
e project is
accepted, in
e College of
e States, and w
at
is discour-
sed, or objected upon it, I shall not knowe so very
soone. For they will canvas it often, according
to their custome. But for
e better assurance of
at
conclusion wee desyre M
r
Barnevelt will traine it
on, till according to
e promise, w
ch
was mutually
made, at
e session of Zyricksea, there shalbe Depu-
ties app ointed out of
Holland
and
Zeland,
to
conferre about it w
t
e States: wherein he hath
already affected so muche w
t
e residue of his
fellowes, as
e Councell of Holland hath written
already their l
res
of Citation to
e townes of their
Province to appeere at
e Hage
e 18 day of Fe
b
after their style, w
t
this clause in their l
res
,
Pour avancer les affaires d'Angleterre
, w
ch
doth
as good as implie
at they should come hither
sufficiently autorised, w
ch
will make it I hope
a very short peece of worke. We have freshe intelligence
heere,
at
e Cardinal of Austriche doth determine for
a while to keepe his Court at
Namur:
but there is no-
thing heere besydes of special consideration. The
most parte of
e horsemen of this Contrey, w
t
certaine
troupes of foote, are gone thitherward of late, to give
his traine an alarme, and to doe some service, if it
may be: wherof and of
e State of all thinges heere,
S
r
Francis Vere
, who is come hither, and will departe w
th
in
these two dayes, will informe you very fully.
And so I take &c. From
e Hage Ja
n
30 95
